title:
Triviality, Rotational Symmetry, and Classification of Complete
  Expanding Gradient Yamabe Solitons

sections.text:
#### Abstract

In this paper, we rigorously analyze the scalar curvature of complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons. We show that if the scalar curvature is less than the soliton constant by an arbitrarily small positive amount, then the soliton is trivial. Additionally, we show that if the scalar curvature is greater than the soliton constant by an arbitrarily small positive amount, then the soliton is rotationally symmetric. Furthermore, we completely classify nontrivial complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons in both cases: when the scalar curvature is greater than the soliton constant and when it is less than the soliton constant.

## 1. InTRODUCTION

The Yamabe flow is a fundamental and highly effective tool for analyzing the structure of manifolds. The study of the Yamabe flow has developed rapidly in the last decades and has become a central area in geometry (cf. [2], [3], [6], [8], [11], [17], [19]). To analyze the Yamabe flow, and more generally, geometric flows, it is important to study singularity models. Yamabe solitons are special solutions to the Yamabe flow and are expected to serve as singularity models (cf. [8]). From this perspective, Yamabe solitons have also been studied extensively over the last few decades (cf. [4], [5], [9], [13], [14]).

An $n$-dimensional Riemannian manifold $\left(M^{n}, g\right)$ is called a gradient Yamabe soliton if there exists a smooth function $F$ on $M$ and a constant $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}$ such that

$$
\nabla \nabla F=(R-\lambda) g
$$

where, $\nabla \nabla F$ is the Hessian of $F$ and $R$ denotes the scalar curvature of $(M, g)$. A gradient Yamabe soliton is represented as $\left(M^{n}, g, F, \lambda\right)$. If $F$ is constant, then the gradient Yamabe soliton is called trivial. If $\lambda>0, \lambda=0$, or $\lambda<0$, then the Yamabe soliton is called shrinking, steady, or expanding.

It is well known that there exist no nontrivial compact gradient Yamabe solitons (cf. [11]). One of the main problems in the study of Yamabe solitons is determining whether complete gradient Yamabe solitons are rotationally symmetric. In particular, the Yamabe soliton version of Perelman's conjecture, which states that "any nontrivial complete steady gradient Yamabe soliton with positive scalar curvature is rotationally symmetric," has stimulated significant interest in this problem. Partial answers have been obtained under the assumption of local conformal flatness (cf. [4], [9]). Catino, Mantegazza and Mazzieri also

provided a partial answer to the conjecture under the assumption that $\operatorname{Ric}(\nabla F, \nabla F) \geq 0$ and $\operatorname{Ric}(\nabla F, \nabla F)>0$ holds at least at one point (cf. [5]). Here, Ric is the Ricci tensor of $M$. Finally, the author resolved the conjecture (cf. [13]). Furthermore, the author also proved the rotational symmetry of the complete shrinking gradient Yamabe solitons under $R>\lambda$, and showed that this assumption is optimal. Therefore, the remaining problem involves expanding solitons. However, the study of expanding solitons has been regarded as difficult so far. In fact, even in low-dimensional cases, expanding gradient Yamabe solitons exhibit richer geometry than steady or shrinking solitons (cf. [1], [14]), making it difficult to obtain rigidity results. To overcome this difficulty, we reduce the problem to the existence and nonexistence of solutions of a certain ODE, using the warped product structure provided by Tashiro's theorem (cf. [18], see also [12]), and then analyze it rigorously.

Theorem 1.1 ([18], [12]). Let $\left(M^{n}, g, F, \varphi\right)$ be a complete Riemannian manifold which satisfies

$$
\varphi g=\nabla \nabla F
$$

for smooth functions $F$ and $\varphi$ on $M$. Then $\left(M^{n}, g, F, \varphi\right)$ is either
(1) compact and rotationally symmetric, or
(2) rotationally symmetric and equal to the warped product

$$
\left([0, \infty), d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(\mathbb{S}^{n-1}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)
$$

where, $\bar{g}_{S}$ is the round metric on $\mathbb{S}^{n-1}$, or
(3) the warped product

$$
\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(N^{n-1}, \bar{g}\right)
$$

In Theorem 1.1, if $\varphi=R-\lambda$, then $\left(M^{n}, g, F, \lambda\right)$ is a gradient Yamabe soliton. Tashiro's theorem is really powerful for studying complete gradient Yamabe solitons. In fact, by the proof of Theorem 1.1 (see [12]), it is easy to see that if $\operatorname{Ric}(\nabla F, \nabla F) \geq 0$ and $\operatorname{Ric}(\nabla F, \nabla F)>$ 0 holds at least at one point, then any such complete Riemannian manifold $(M, g, F, \varphi)$ with a non-constant function $F$ is rotationally symmetric. Therefore, in the study of the rotational symmetry of complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons, imposing conditions on the scalar curvature is of fundamental importance. To analyze the scalar curvature in cases (2) and (3) of Theorem 1.1, the following equations, derived from the structure of the warped product, are used.

$$
|\nabla F|^{2} R=\bar{R}-(n-1)(n-2)(R-\lambda)^{2}-2(n-1) g(\nabla F, \nabla R)
$$

Here, we note that $F$ depends only on $r$ and $F^{\prime}(r)>0$ (cf. [18], see also [12]). Set $\rho=F^{\prime}$. Then we have

$$
2(n-1) \rho \rho^{\prime \prime}+(n-1)(n-2) \rho^{\prime 2}+\rho^{2}\left(\rho^{\prime}+\lambda\right)=\bar{R}
$$

Hence, the scalar curvature $\bar{R}$ of $N$ is constant. Differentiating both sides of (1.1),

$$
2(n-1)^{2} \rho^{\prime} \rho^{\prime \prime}+2(n-1) \rho \rho^{\prime \prime \prime}+2 \rho \rho^{\prime}\left(\rho^{\prime}+\lambda\right)+\rho^{2} \rho^{\prime \prime}=0
$$

Note that, since low dimensional complete gradient solitons have already been classified (cf. $[1,14])$, we focus on the case $n=\operatorname{dim} M \geq 3$ in this paper.

# 2. EXAMPLES, TRIVIALITY AND ROTATIONAL SYMMETRY 

To study rotational symmetry of complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons, we first note that there exist nontrivial examples when $R=\lambda$ (cf. [14]).
Example. Let $\left(N^{n-1}, \bar{g}\right)$ be an $(n-1)$-dimensional complete Riemannian manifold with constant negative scalar curvature $\bar{R}$. Then, for any $\alpha \in \mathbb{R},(M, g, F, \lambda)=\left(\mathbb{R} \times N^{n-1}, d r^{2}+\right.$ $\left.\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda} \bar{g}, \sqrt{\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda}} r+\alpha, \lambda\right)$ is an $n$-dimensional complete expanding gradient Yamabe soliton with $R=\lambda$.

In particular, $\left(M^{3}, g, F, \lambda\right)=\left(\mathbb{R} \times \mathbb{H}^{2}, d r^{2}+\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda} \bar{g}_{H}, \sqrt{\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda}} r+\alpha, \lambda\right)$ is a 3-dimensional complete expanding gradient Yamabe soliton with $R=\lambda$, where $\left(\mathbb{H}^{2}, \bar{g}_{H}\right)$ is a hyperbolic surface.

Therefore, imposing conditions on the scalar curvature is crucial and fundamental for achieving rotational symmetry in complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons. In particular, the problem reduces to the cases $R>\lambda$ or $R<\lambda$.

Interestingly, the following triviality result for expanding, steady, and shrinking solitons can be obtained for any $\varepsilon>0$ provided that $R<\lambda-\varepsilon$.
Proposition 2.1. If $R<\lambda-\varepsilon$ for some $\varepsilon>0$, then there exists no nontrivial complete gradient Yamabe solitons.

Proof. If $M$ is compact, it is trivial. Hence, we consider the other cases. If $R<\lambda-\varepsilon$, then one has that the positive smooth function $\rho$ satisfies $\rho^{\prime}<-\varepsilon$. Therefore, we have a contradiction.

On the other hand, if $R>\lambda+\varepsilon$, then the soliton is rotationally symmetric.
Proposition 2.2. Let $(M, g, F, \lambda)$ be a nontrivial complete expanding gradient Yamabe soliton. If $R>\lambda+\varepsilon$ for some $\varepsilon>0$, then it is rotationally symmetric and equal to the warped product

$$
\left([0, \infty), d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(\mathbb{S}^{n-1}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)
$$

Proof. Since there exists no compact gradient Yamabe solitons, we only have to consider (3) of Theorem 1.1. Since $\rho^{\prime}>\varepsilon$ and $\rho>0$, we have a contradiction.

As a corollary, we obtain rotational symmetry of complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons with positive scalar curvature.

Corollary 2.3. Any nontrivial complete expanding gradient Yamabe soliton with positive scalar curvature is rotationally symmetric.

This generalizes Theorem 1.3 in [9], Corollary 3.3 in [5] and Corollary 1.6 in [4]. In particular, we remove the assumption of local conformal flatness.

The remaining cases are $R>\lambda$ and $R<\lambda$.

## 3. CASE $R<\lambda$

In this section, we consider the case $R<\lambda$, and completely classify complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons with $R<\lambda$.

Proposition 3.1. A complete nontrivial, expanding gradient Yamabe soliton $\left(M^{n}, g, F, \lambda\right)$ with $R<\lambda$ is either
(1) the warped product

$$
\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(N^{n-1}(0), \bar{g}\right)
$$

where $\left(N^{n-1}(0), \bar{g}\right)$ has flat scalar curvature, and the scalar curvature of $M$ tends to $\lambda$ at infinity, or
(2) the warped product

$$
\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(N^{n-1}\left(-c^{2}\right), \bar{g}\right)
$$

where $\left(N^{n-1}\left(-c^{2}\right), \bar{g}\right)$ has negative constant scalar curvature, and the scalar curvature of $M$ tends to $\lambda$ at infinity.
Furthermore, the potential function $F$ satisfies $F^{\prime \prime}(r)<0, F^{\prime \prime \prime}(r)>0$ and $F^{\prime}(r) \searrow \sqrt{\frac{R}{\lambda}}$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$, where $\bar{R}$ is the scalar curvature of $N$.

Proof. By the assumption we have $\rho^{\prime}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. If $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$, then $\rho$ is a positive concave function. Hence, $\rho$ is constant, which is a contradiction.

Assume that there exists $\tilde{r} \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $\rho^{\prime \prime}(\tilde{r})=0$. By (1.2),

$$
\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}=-\frac{\rho^{\prime}\left(\rho^{\prime}+\lambda\right)}{n-1}<0
$$

at $\tilde{r}$. By iterating the same argument, $\rho^{\prime}$ is weakly monotone decreasing on $(\tilde{r},+\infty)$. Since $\rho^{\prime}<0, \rho^{\prime}<-\gamma^{2}$ for some constant $\gamma$ on $\left(\tilde{r}_{2},+\infty\right)$ for some $\tilde{r}_{2}$. Since $\rho>0$, we have a contradiction. Hence, $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. Since $\rho>0$, we have $\rho \searrow c(\geq 0)$ and $\rho^{\prime} \nearrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$.

Case I $c>0$. By (1.1),

$$
\rho^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow \frac{\bar{R}-c^{2} \lambda}{2(n-1) c}
$$

as $r \nearrow+\infty$. We have three cases.
Case $1 \bar{R}>c^{2} \lambda$. Since $\rho^{\prime}<0$, we have a contradiction.
Case $2 \bar{R}<c^{2} \lambda$. Since $\rho>0$, we have a contradiction.
Case $3 \bar{R}=c^{2} \lambda$. We have $\rho^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$.
Case II $c=0$. By (1.1), we have the following three cases.
Case $1 \bar{R}>0$. We have $\rho^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow+\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. We have a contradiction, because $\rho^{\prime}<0$.
Case $2 \bar{R}<0$. We have $\rho^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow-\infty$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$. We have a contradiction, because $\rho>0$.
Case $3 \bar{R}=0$. We have $\rho^{\prime \prime} \rightarrow 0$ as $r \nearrow+\infty$.

# 4. CASE $R>\lambda$ 

We finally consider the case $R>\lambda$. Interestingly, in this case, for (3) of Theorem 1.1, the scalar curvature of $M$ must be negative:

Theorem 4.1. Let $\left(M^{n}, g, F, \lambda\right)$ be a complete nontrivial, expanding gradient Yamabe soliton with $R>\lambda$. Assume that $F$ has no critical point, then it is the warped product

$$
\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(N^{n-1}, \bar{g}\right)
$$

where, $N$ has constant scalar curvature $\bar{R}$. Furthermore, $\bar{R} \leq 0$ and $\lambda<R<0$. Moreover, the potential function $F$ satisfies $\lim _{r \rightarrow-\infty} F^{\prime}(r)=\sqrt{\frac{R}{\lambda}}, F^{\prime \prime}(r)>0$ and $F^{\prime \prime \prime}(r) \geq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. However, there exists no open interval on which $F^{\prime \prime \prime}(r)=0$.

As a corollary, one can classify expanding gradient Yamabe solitons with $R>\lambda$.
Corollary 4.2. A complete nontrivial, expanding gradient Yamabe soliton $\left(M^{n}, g, F, \lambda\right)$ with $R>\lambda$ is either
(1) rotationally symmetric and equal to the warped product

$$
\left([0,+\infty), d r^{2}\right) \times_{\mid \nabla F \mid}\left(\mathbb{S}^{n-1}, \bar{g}_{S}\right)
$$

where, $\bar{g}_{S}$ is the round metric on $\mathbb{S}^{n-1}$, or
(2) the warped product

$$
\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(N^{n-1}(0), \bar{g}\right)
$$

which satisfies $\lambda<R<0$, where $\left(N^{n-1}(0), \bar{g}\right)$ has flat scalar curvature, or
(3) the warped product

$$
\left(\mathbb{R}, d r^{2}\right) \times_{|\nabla F|}\left(N^{n-1}\left(-c^{2}\right), \bar{g}\right)
$$

which satisfies $\lambda<R<0$, where $\left(N^{n-1}\left(-c^{2}\right), \bar{g}\right)$ has negative constant scalar curvature.
Furthermore, in the cases (2) and (3), the potential function $F$ satisfies $\lim _{r \rightarrow-\infty} F^{\prime}(r)=$ $\sqrt{\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda}}, F^{\prime \prime}(r)>0$ and $F^{\prime \prime \prime}(r) \geq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. However, there exists no open interval on which $F^{\prime \prime \prime}(r)=0$.

Proof of Theorem 4.1. We show that the scalar curvature $\bar{R}$ of $N$ in (3) of Theorem 1.1 is nonpositive.

Claim 1. The scalar curvature $\bar{R}$ of $N$ in (3) of Theorem 1.1 is nonpositive.
Proof of Claim1. Assume that $\bar{R}$ is positive. Set $s=-r$. Since $\dot{\rho}=-\rho^{\prime}(<0), \ddot{\rho}=\rho^{\prime \prime}$, and $\ddot{\rho}=-\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}$, the equations (1.1) and (1.2) are as follows.

$$
2(n-1) \rho \ddot{\rho}+(n-1)(n-2) \dot{\rho}^{2}+\rho^{2}(-\dot{\rho}+\lambda)=\bar{R}
$$

and

$$
-2(n-1)^{2} \dot{\rho} \ddot{\rho}-2(n-1) \rho \ddot{\rho}-2 \rho \dot{\rho}(-\dot{\rho}+\lambda)+\rho^{2} \ddot{\rho}=0
$$

If $\ddot{\rho}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$, then we have a contradiction, because $\rho>0$.
Assume that there exists $\tilde{s} \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $\ddot{\rho}=0$. Then one has

$$
\ddot{\rho}(\tilde{s})=-\frac{\dot{\rho}(\tilde{s})(-\dot{\rho}(\tilde{s})+\lambda)}{n-1}
$$

We have three cases.
If $-\dot{\rho}(\tilde{s})+\lambda>0$, then $\ddot{\rho}(\tilde{s})>0$. By (4.1), we have

$$
\dot{\rho}=\frac{\rho^{2} \pm \sqrt{\rho^{4}-4(n-1)(n-2)\left(\lambda \rho^{2}-\bar{R}\right)}}{2(n-1)(n-2)}
$$

at $\tilde{s}$. Since $\dot{\rho}<0$, one has

$$
-2(n-1)(n-2) \lambda+\rho^{2}<-2(n-1)(n-2) \dot{\rho}+\rho^{2}=\sqrt{\rho^{4}-4(n-1)(n-2)\left(\lambda \rho^{2}-\bar{R}\right)}
$$

at $\tilde{s}$. Since the both sides of the above inequality are positive, one has

$$
(n-1)(n-2) \lambda^{2}<\bar{R}
$$

By the same argument, if $-\dot{\rho}(\tilde{s})+\lambda<0$, that is $\vec{\rho}(\tilde{s})<0$, then one has

$$
(n-1)(n-2) \lambda^{2}>\bar{R}
$$

and if $-\dot{\rho}(\tilde{s})+\lambda=0$, that is $\vec{\rho}(\tilde{s})=0$, then one has

$$
(n-1)(n-2) \lambda^{2}=\bar{R}
$$

Therefore, if there exists a point $\tilde{s}$ such that $\ddot{\rho}=0, \vec{\rho}$ has the same behavior.
Case 1. If $-\dot{\rho}+\lambda>0$ at the point $\tilde{s}$, then $\vec{\rho}(\tilde{s})>0$ and $\dot{\rho}$ is weakly monotone increasing on $(\tilde{s},+\infty)$. One has $\rho\searrow c(\geq 0)$ and $\dot{\rho} \nearrow 0$ as $s \nearrow+\infty$.

If $c>0$, by $(4.1)$,

$$
\ddot{\rho} \rightarrow \frac{\bar{R}-c^{2} \lambda}{2(n-1) c}(>0)
$$

as $s \nearrow+\infty$. Since $\dot{\rho}<0$, we have a contradiction.
If $c=0$, by (4.1) again, $\ddot{\rho} \nearrow+\infty$ as $s \nearrow+\infty$. Since $\dot{\rho}<0$, we have a contradiction.
Case 2. If $-\dot{\rho}+\lambda<0$ at the point $\tilde{s}$, then $\vec{\rho}(\tilde{s})<0$ and $\dot{\rho}$ is weakly monotone decreasing on $(\tilde{s},+\infty)$. Hence, one has $\dot{\rho}<-\gamma^{2}$ for some constant $\gamma$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{2},+\infty\right)$ for some $\tilde{s}_{2}$. Since $\rho>0$, we have a contradiction.

Case 3. If $-\dot{\rho}+\lambda=0$ at the point $\tilde{s}$, then $(n-1)(n-2) \lambda^{2}=\bar{R}$. By (4.1), we have

$$
2(n-1) \rho \ddot{\rho}=(-\dot{\rho}+\lambda)\left\{(n-1)(n-2) \lambda+\left(n^{2}-3 n+1\right) \dot{\rho}\right\}
$$

Hence, the points satisfying $\ddot{\rho}=0$ coincide with those satisfying $\dot{\rho}=\lambda$. Therefore, we only need to consider the following three cases.

Case $1 \dot{\rho}>\lambda$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{3},+\infty\right)$ for some $\tilde{s}_{3}$. In this case, $\ddot{\rho}>0$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{3},+\infty\right)$ and one has $\dot{\rho}>\beta(>\lambda)$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{4},+\infty\right)$ for some $\tilde{s}_{4}$. Hence, we have $\ddot{\rho}>\gamma(>0)$ for some constant $\gamma$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{4},+\infty\right)$. Since $\dot{\rho}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$, we have a contradiction.

Case $2 \dot{\rho}<\lambda$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{3},+\infty\right)$ for some $\tilde{s}_{3}$. In this case, we have $\ddot{\rho}<0$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{3},+\infty\right)$. Since $\rho>0$ on $\mathbb{R}$, we have a contradiction.

Case $3 \dot{\rho}=\lambda$ on $\left(\tilde{s}_{3},+\infty\right)$ for some $\tilde{s}_{3}$. Since $\rho>0$ on $\mathbb{R}$, we have a contradiction.
Therefore there exists no such the point $\tilde{s}$. Hence one has $\ddot{\rho}>0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. We have $\rho \searrow c(\geq 0)$ for some $c \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\dot{\rho} \nearrow 0$ as $s \nearrow+\infty$.

Case $1 c>0$. By (4.1), we have

$$
\ddot{\rho} \rightarrow-\frac{\bar{R}-\lambda c^{2}}{2(n-1) c}(<0)
$$

as $s \nearrow+\infty$. Since $\rho>0$, we have a contradiction.
Case $2 c=0$. By (4.1), we have $\ddot{\rho} \rightarrow+\infty$ as $s \nearrow+\infty$. Since $\dot{\rho}<0$, we have a contradiction.

Therefore, one has $\bar{R} \leq 0$. Under the assumption the following claim holds.

Claim 2. If there exists a point $r_{0} \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $\rho^{\prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=0$, then $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)>0$. Furthermore, we also have $\sqrt{\frac{R}{\lambda}}<\rho\left(r_{0}\right)$.
Proof of Claim 2.
Case 1. $\bar{R}=0$. Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=0$. By (1.1),

$$
(n-1)(n-2) \rho^{\prime 2}\left(r_{0}\right)+\rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right) \rho^{\prime}\left(e_{0}\right)=-\lambda \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)
$$

Hence, one has

$$
\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=\frac{-\rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right) \pm \sqrt{\rho^{4}\left(r_{0}\right)-4(n-1)(n-2) \lambda \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)}}{2(n-1)(n-2)}
$$

Since $\rho^{\prime}>0$, it must be

$$
\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=\frac{-\rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)+\sqrt{\rho^{4}\left(r_{0}\right)-4(n-1)(n-2) \lambda \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right))}}{2(n-1)(n-2)}
$$

Furthermore, by (1.2),

$$
\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=-\frac{1}{n-1} \rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)\left(\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)+\lambda\right)
$$

Since $\rho^{\prime}>0$, we have 3 cases.
(1) Assume that $-\lambda<\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)$. Combining this inequality with (4.3), we have

$$
-\lambda<\frac{-\rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)+\sqrt{\rho^{4}\left(r_{0}\right)-4(n-1)(n-2) \lambda \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right))}}{2(n-1)(n-2)}
$$

A straightforward computation leads to a contradiction.
(2) Assume that $-\lambda=\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)$. A similar argument shows that $\lambda=0$, which is a contradiction.

Hence, the inequality $-\lambda>\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)$ holds and one has $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)>0$.
Case 2. $\bar{R}<0$. Assume that $\rho^{\prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=0$. By (1.1),

$$
(n-1)(n-2) \rho^{\prime 2}\left(r_{0}\right)+\rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right) \rho^{\prime}\left(e_{0}\right)=\bar{R}-\lambda \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)
$$

Hence, one has

$$
\rho^{4}\left(r_{0}\right)-4 \lambda(n-1)(n-2) \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)+4(n-1)(n-2) \bar{R}>0
$$

and

$$
\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=\frac{-\rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right) \pm \sqrt{\rho^{4}\left(r_{0}\right)+4(n-1)(n-2)\left(\bar{R}-\lambda \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)\right)}}{2(n-1)(n-2)}
$$

Since $\rho^{\prime}>0$, one has

$$
\sqrt{\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda}}<\rho\left(r_{0}\right)
$$

and

$$
\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=\frac{-\rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)+\sqrt{\rho^{4}\left(r_{0}\right)+4(n-1)(n-2)\left(\bar{R}-\lambda \rho^{2}\left(r_{0}\right)\right)}}{2(n-1)(n-2)}
$$

Furthermore, by (1.2),

$$
\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)=-\frac{1}{n-1} \rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)\left(\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{0}\right)+\lambda\right)
$$

Since $\rho^{\prime}>0$, the similar argument shows that $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(r_{0}\right)>0$.

Assume that there exists $r_{1} \in \mathbb{R}$ such that $\rho^{\prime}\left(r_{1}\right)=-\lambda$. By (1.1), we have $\rho^{\prime \prime}\left(r_{1}\right)<0$. Hence, there exists no point $r_{-1} \in\left(-\infty, r_{1}\right)$ such that $\rho^{\prime \prime}\left(r_{-1}\right)=0$. In fact, if there exists such a point, then by the claim, $\rho^{\prime \prime \prime}\left(r_{-1}\right)>0$ and the function $\rho^{\prime}$ is weakly monotone increasing on $\left(r_{-1},+\infty\right)$. By the same reason, it cannot happen that $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ at some point on $\left(-\infty, r_{1}\right)$. Therefore, we have $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(-\infty, r_{2}\right)$ for some $r_{2}\left(>r_{1}\right)$. However, since $\rho>0, \rho^{\prime}>0$ and $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\left(-\infty, r_{2}\right)$, we have a contradiction. Hence, such a point $r_{1}$ does not exist, and one has $\rho^{\prime}>-\lambda$ or $\rho^{\prime}<-\lambda$ on $\mathbb{R}$. By Proposition 2.2, the first case cannot happen. Therefore, $\lambda<R<0$.

Claim 2 shows that for each critical point $r_{0}$ of $\rho^{\prime}$, the function $\rho^{\prime}$ is weakly monotone increasing on $\left(r_{0},+\infty\right)$. Assume that $\rho^{\prime}$ has a critical point $r_{0}$, and furthermore, if there exists an interval on which $\rho^{\prime}$ is decreasing, then without loss of generality, we may assume that it is $\left(-\infty, r_{0}\right)$. However, by the same argument as before, we have a contradiction. Therefore, $\rho^{\prime}$ is weakly monotone increasing on $\mathbb{R}$. If there exists no critical point of $\rho^{\prime}$, we have $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$ or $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ on $\mathbb{R}$. However, $\rho^{\prime \prime}<0$ cannot happen. Hence, one has $\rho^{\prime \prime}>0$.

Therefore, $\rho^{\prime \prime} \geq 0$ on $\mathbb{R}$ and there exists no open interval on which $\rho^{\prime \prime}=0$. Set $s=-r$ as in the proof of Claim 1. Since $\rho>0$ and $\dot{\rho}<0$, we have $\rho \searrow c(\geq 0)$ for some $c \in \mathbb{R}$, and $\dot{\rho} \nearrow 0$ as $s \nearrow+\infty$.

Case $1 c>0$. By (4.1), $\ddot{\rho}$ need to converse to some constant $C(\geq 0)$. If $C>0$, since $\dot{\rho}<0$, we have a contradiction. If $C=0$, we have $\lambda c^{2}=\bar{R}$.

Case $2 c=0$. By (4.1) again, since $\ddot{\rho} \geq 0, \bar{R}$ must be zero.
Therefore, we have

$$
\bar{R}=\lambda \lim _{r \rightarrow-\infty} \rho^{2}(r)
$$

and $F^{\prime}(r)>\sqrt{\frac{\bar{R}}{\lambda}}$ on $\mathbb{R}$.

# REFERENCES

abstract:
In this paper, we rigorously analyze the scalar curvature of complete
expanding gradient Yamabe solitons. We show that if the scalar curvature is
less than the soliton constant by an arbitrarily small positive amount, then
the soliton is trivial. Additionally, we show that if the scalar curvature is
greater than the soliton constant by an arbitrarily small positive amount, then
the soliton is rotationally symmetric. Furthermore, we completely classify
nontrivial complete expanding gradient Yamabe solitons in both cases: when the
scalar curvature is greater than the soliton constant and when it is less than
the soliton constant.
